I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will improve the production system, 
productivity, and competitiveness of Armenia’s agriculture sector. It will promote holistic value 
chain development for high-value crops from production to market. It will also increase the 
institutional capacity of sector agencies to develop and adopt appropriate policies and regulations 
to unlock the potential of the agriculture sector.1 
 
2.  The Government of Armenia has requested the assistance of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) to revitalize the agriculture sector through enhancing value addition by diversifying 
and increasing the productivity of high-value crops.2 The TA is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030 
in promoting rural development and food security through (i) improving market connectivity and 
agricultural value chain linkages, (ii) increasing agricultural productivity and food security, and (iii) 
enhancing food safety.3 ADB’s country partnership strategy for Armenia supports an export-
oriented  and  inclusive  economy  meeting  high  technological,  industrial,  and  environmental 
standards.4 The TA is included in ADB’s country operations business plan, 2020–2022.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Agriculture’s share of Armenia’s gross domestic product has declined in recent years, from 
18% in 2012 to 14% in 2018. However, agriculture continues to provide a significant source of 
employment, employing 33.3% of the labor force in 2018; women provided about 56% of 
agricultural labor.6 According to the Food and Agriculture Organization, Armenia’s agricultural 
land  totals  2.04 million  hectares  (ha),  but  only  22%  (446,000  ha)  is  arable.  Agriculture  is 
predominantly  smallholder-based,  with  an  average  landholding  of  1.5  ha.  Crop  production 
accounts for 72% and livestock production accounts for 28% of agricultural value added. In 2017, 
the distribution of area harvested by crop was cereals (32%); fruit (49%); vegetables, roots, and 
pulses (17%); and nuts (1%).7 Growth in agriculture is constrained by low-value crops, low 
productivity, limited connectivity and weak market linkages, inadequate public investment, and 
sporadic support services. Less than 30% of arable land has irrigation facilities. Armenia is a net 
importer of agricultural and food products, with exports of $697 million and imports of $726 million 
in 2018. The level of Armenia’s self-sufficiency is low for some key products—in particular, 33% 
for wheat products, 58% for pork products, and 23% for poultry products. 
 
4.  The sector has suffered from limited access to good quality land, specialized agricultural 
machinery, appropriate inputs, modern technologies, market information, modern distribution 
methods, commercial finance, and crop insurance. The agricultural value chain is characterized 
by rudimentary marketing and transportation infrastructure, weak linkages between value chain 
actors, and limited and technologically poor storage and processing capacity. There is no strategic 
coordination  of  wholesale  market  activity  at  the  national  level.  All  markets  nationwide  are 
                                                
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 15 July 2019. 
2  The TA may consider livestock production, processing, and marketing, subject to further assessment during 
implementation. 
3  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila.  
4  ADB. 2019. Country Partnership Strategy: Armenia, 2019-2023—Fostering Inclusive, Diversified, and Transformative 
Growth. Manila.  
5  ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: Armenia, 2020-2022. Manila.  
6  World  Bank.  GDP:  Agriculture,  forestry,  and  fishing,  value  added  (%  of  GDP)--Armenia; and World  Bank. 
Employment in agriculture (% of total employment) (modeled ILO estimate)–Armenia (accessed 15 November 2019). 
7  Food and Agriculture Organization Corporate Statistical Database (FAOSTAT). Food and agriculture data (accessed 
15 November 2019).

2 
managed at the local level, which has given rise to a range of wholesale and retail market outlets 
of varying capacities and levels of professionalism. Public investment in agricultural research and 
development, extension services, and agribusiness development has been negligible, and private 
sector efforts are limited. Linkages with agricultural universities and academic institutions are 
weak. In the horticulture subsector, productivity is low because the industry is highly fragmented. 
Producers are predominantly individual farmers and small enterprises with no access to advanced 
horticultural  techniques,  productive  seeds,  effective  plant  nutrients  and  pesticides,  efficient 
logistics,  and  appropriate  financial  resources  and  services.  In  addition,  the  industry  faces 
emerging challenges, such as shortage of arable land and water resources, greater focus on 
environmental protection, frequent natural disasters that increase price volatility, insufficient 
agricultural infrastructure, low incomes for rural farmers, and a growing need for rural reform to 
ensure the sector’s development. 
 
5.  Armenia’s agriculture sector is highly susceptible to climate change, given its mountainous 
terrain, slow adoption of climate change adaptation and mitigation, and small area of arable land. 
The subsistence nature of agricultural production has led to unsustainable production practices 
and overgrazing of pastures, causing serious soil erosion. About 80% of agricultural land is 
subject to some form of degradation. About 20% of arable land is eroded, and salinity affects 
about 20% of the irrigated area. Projections indicate that by 2030, climate hazards such as 
decreased and more variable precipitation, higher temperatures, and reduced river runoff could 
result in reduced, less certain, and lower crop and livestock yields and/or crop failure. Crop and 
livestock yields could drop by an estimated 7%–24%.8 The extent and degree of losses in crop 
and livestock outputs would negatively impact the Armenian economy, because agriculture is the 
main source of livelihoods for Armenia’s rural population. 
 
6.  Opportunities.  Armenia  has  the  potential  to  raise  agricultural  productivity  and 
competitiveness, despite the degradation of agricultural land. Armenia’s climate is similar to that 
of the world’s leading fruit and vegetable export regions. Armenia is also strategically located to 
benefit from international trade in high-value crops. To promote agricultural trade, Armenia signed 
a Comprehensive and Enhanced Partnership Agreement in November 2017, which aims to 
strengthen political and economic cooperation. Armenia also benefits from the Generalised 
Scheme of Preferences (GSP+) of the European Union (EU): under the GSP+, the total value of 
preferential imports from Armenia into the EU increased from €42 million in 2014 to €135 million 
in 2017.9 Through these agreements, Armenia is expected to be able to transform its fragmented 
and subsistence-based agriculture sector to one that is profitable, competitive, and export-
oriented. The Eurasian Economic Union (EEU) also offers opportunities for growth and a market 
of about 183 million people. Armenia acceded to the EEU in 2015; previously, it already had 
several free trade agreements with EEU member countries. 
 
7.  Government’s sector strategy. In February 2019, the government released a new 
economic development strategy.10 In agriculture, the strategy aims to increase productivity, 
introduce  modern  technologies,  improve  food  quality  and  safety  standards,  enhance 
competitiveness, increase exports, and raise the incomes of all value chain participants. The TA 
will help implement the strategy and its sector-specific policy initiatives, including the draft 
Strategy for Sustainable Agricultural Development (Vision 2029) under review by the government 
as of October 2019. 
                                                
8  World Bank. 2014. Reducing the Vulnerability of Armenia’s Agricultural Systems to Climate Change: Impact 
Assessment and Adaptation Options. Washington, DC. 
9  European Commission. Armenia: Trade Picture (accessed 28 October 2019). 
10 Government of Armenia. 2019. Decision No 65-A of 8 February 2019 on the Programme of the Government of the 
Republic of Armenia. Yerevan.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  agricultural  competitiveness  enhanced 
(footnote 10). The TA will have the following outcome: production and marketing of high-value 
crops increased.11 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  The outputs of the TA will be: (i) policies and regulations for high-value crop diversification 
improved and (ii) suitable financing mechanisms for high-value crop diversification developed. 
 
10.  Output 1: Policies and regulations for high-value crop diversification improved. The 
TA will help the Ministry of Economy formulate policies, regulations, and related implementation 
and monitoring mechanisms to help diversify, improve productivity, and realize export potential 
for  high-value  crops.  Through  analysis  of  constraints  and  opportunities  in  producing  and 
marketing high-value crops and consultation with sector stakeholders, the TA will recommend a 
range  of  high-value  crops  that meets  market demand  and suits  Armenia’s  agro-ecological 
conditions, and propose a strategy to promote identified crops in domestic and international 
markets.In parallel, the TA will elaborate a systematic approach to (i) enhance land administration, 
 
(ii) develop agricultural value chain infrastructure, and (iii) improve agricultural competitiveness 
and  risk  mitigation  and  management,  and  increase  exports  to  EU  markets,  including 
enhancement of transport links to export markets through regional cooperation. Throughout, the 
TA  will  assess  the  constraints,  opportunities,  and  appropriate  policy  initiatives  to  enhance 
participation and income-earning potential for women in high-value crop production and marketing. 
 
11.  Output  2:  Suitable  financing  mechanisms  for  high-value  crop  diversification 
developed.  The  TA  will  first  conduct  a  gap  analysis  of  current  financing  and  institutional 
arrangements for agricultural value chain development. The TA will also review best international 
practices of financing and private and/or public–private investment mechanisms suitable to 
modernize agriculture and diversify crops, including risk management instruments for value-chain 
financing, e.g., repurchase agreements, trade receivables finance, trader finance, warehouse 
receipts, and commodity finance. Farm-specific assessments will evaluate farmers’ financial and 
technical capacity and the farming system’s suitability for high-value crop diversification. The 
assessments will review the role of women in high-value crop farming and identify financing 
mechanisms to enhance the participation of women as entrepreneurs, not only as providers of 
labor. Based on the analyses, the TA will:  
(i)   recommend financing and institutional mechanisms for  
(a)   provision  of  agricultural  value  chain  infrastructure,  in  particular,  lease 
finance and alternative financing modalities for harvest- and post-harvest 
facilities and other farming and marketing facilities; and  
(b)   crop production, insurance, processing, and storage, with potential public–
private partnership or full private sector financing;  
(ii)   prepare and implement a plan to increase the capacity of relevant agencies for 
new financing mechanisms; and  
(iii)   develop an investment project proposal for high-value crop diversification, which 
will  include  innovative  features,  climate  change  adaptation  and  mitigation 
measures, gender development, and relevant thematic issues. 
                                                
11 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
 
12.  Lessons and ADB’s value addition. Lessons from both in-country and regional sector 
operations call for the critical need to (i) adopt a medium-term approach informed by a greater 
understanding of the complexity of reforms and the capacity of institutions to implement reforms; 
(ii) ensure continuity in capacity-building support; (iii) develop modern production, post-harvest, 
and marketing systems; (iv) follow an integrated value chain development approach to maximize 
overall productivity and efficiency gains; and (v) promote collaboration between key value chain 
actors led by the private sector to facilitate horizontal and vertical integration and reduce the state 
fiscal burden. The TA will address critical areas that constrain Armenia’s capacity to enhance 
competitiveness of agriculture. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $850,000, of which $750,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space and utilities, meeting venue, data 
and information access, coordination with government agencies, and other in-kind contributions. 
The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. The Ministry of Economy will be the executing agency. ADB 
will  select,  supervise,  and  evaluate  consultants.  The  Environment,  Natural  Resources  and 
Agriculture Division of ADB’s Central and West Asia Department will be the focal point in ADB for 
the TA implementation.  
 
15.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

5 
16.  Consulting services. The TA requires 16 person-months of international consulting 
services and 22 person-months of national consulting services.12 ADB will engage the consultants 
through individual consultant selection following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to 
Armenia for Enhancing High-Value Crop Diversification, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.
                                                
12 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Key Activities with Milestones 
1. Policies and regulations for high-value crop diversification improved 
1.1. Conduct analysis of constraints and opportunities for high-value crops by Q4 2020. 
1.2. Recommend specific measures for implementing the strategy for sustainable agricultural 
development by Q1 2021. 
1.3. Elaborate approach to (i) enhance land administration, (ii) develop agricultural value chain 
infrastructure, and (iii) improve agricultural competitiveness and risk mitigation and management by 
Q3 2021. 
1.4. Assist departments of the Ministry of Economy in policy implementation and monitoring mechanisms 
until Q4 2022. 
2. Suitable financing mechanisms for high-value crop diversification developed 
2.1 Conduct a gap analysis of current financing and institutional arrangements for agricultural value chain 
development by Q4 2020. 
2.2 Review best international practices in financing and private or public–private investment mechanisms 
by Q4 2020. 
2.3 Undertake stakeholder surveys and consultation and evaluate farmers’ financial and technical 
capacity and the farming system’s suitability for the recommended high-value crop diversification by 
Q1 2021. 
2.4 Develop the investment project proposal for high-value crop diversification by Q3 2021. 
TA Management Activities 
Mobilize consultants by March 2020. 
Prepare quarterly progress reports. 
Prepare inception report by April 2020, interim report by March 2022, and final report by September 2023.
